title: Emblematica Online

last_post.content:
So, what is an emblem book anyway?

A typical emblem book consists is a composition of a brief motto (usually in Latin), an enigmatic picture (a "pictura"), and an epigram (subscriptio). The chosen example is from A. de Bourgogne's 1665 "Mundi lapis lydius" and can be accessed here: http://emblematica.library.illinois.edu/detail/emblem/E013126

In this example, the combined story of this emblem is about the contrast between vanitas and veritas ....

2/5

last_post.content:
Cute lil radial menu using CSS trig functions 🙂

The radius is the size of the button + some extra space. Once you know the radius, the X coordinate is cos(radius), and Y coordinate in sin(radius)

Position each item based on its angle from the center.

Add some color, a delay, and a little bonus rotation ✨

Learn more about CSS Trigonometry functions with some dope demos by @bramus here:

title: Groups blocking journalists on Mastodon reaches 200

last_post.content:
This story is so full of alarmism that I feel the need to offer further context.

There are ~12,000 Mastodon servers according to fediverse.observer, a site that tends to undercount nodes.

(This is in contrast to the-federation.info which counts 25,000 Fediverse servers.)

Anyway, even with fediverse.observer’s very conservative count, only 1.7% of Mastodon is blocking journa.host.

So what if 200 servers are blocking journa.host?

title: CSS-only Widgets Are Inaccessible

last_post.content:
*sigh*

Just because someone claims a _thing_ is “accessible” does not make it so.

Failing WCAG, the bare minimum, can be confirmed with a quick automated check: nested interactives (1.3.1/4.1.2), not dismissable (1.4.13), hidden items get focus (2.4.7), state not conveyed (4.1.2), heading mismatch (1.3.1/2.4.6).

This demonstrates why CSS-only widgets are inaccessible: https://adrianroselli.com/2023/03/css-only-widgets-are-inaccessible.html

#a11y #accessibility

Hello friends, I am currently available for work in digital/web #accessibility. Based in Sheffield UK but remote preferred, can negotiate.

I’m looking for a role that’s people oriented so things like training, talks, workshops; anything where I get to chat to folks about making software more inclusive and accessible. I want to work somewhere where the needs of disabled users come first and where I can use my lived experience as a disabled person to educate and inform.

I also have a lot of experience with accessibility testing and auditing, so I’m after somewhere that has a holistic approach to testing such as working alongside delivery teams, assisting with user research or using techniques like demos and barrier walkthroughs. I’m especially into helping teams once the testing has landed to prioritise and go about improvement beyond compliance.

If you would like more of a chat, email me (chad.gowler@proton.me) or check out my LinkedIn profile https://uk.linkedin.com/in/kitation #GetFediHired

title: Return of the Gedi: space mission that maps Earth’s forests saved from destruction

last_post.content:
The Global Ecosystem Dynamics Investigation (GEDI) ISS mission - which 3D maps Earth's forests and is critical to understanding interactions between biodiversity and climate change - was about to be decomissioned and incinerated in the atmosphere (the poetry). Following a last minute call for reprieve from forest ecologists, Nasa will now keep it running until the end of the decade.

https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/mar/28/return-of-gedi-space-mission-maps-earths-forests-saved-from-destruction-aoe

title: ChatGPT - the impact of Large Language Models on Law Enforcement | Europol

last_post.content:
🇪🇺 Europol published a report on ChatGPT and law enforcement (that was fast!)

They say "LLMs have a real impact that can be seen already" but unfortunately provide no reference.

The main risk, says Europol, are fraud (e.g. the CEO scam, because ChatGPT can give answers that sound like your boss') and crime (because ChatGPT can provide malware code to script kiddies).

Europol also encourages police forces to use LLMs (because... tech needs to be "leveraged" apparently)

https://www.europol.europa.eu/publications-events/publications/chatgpt-impact-of-large-language-models-law-enforcement

title: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2301.10226.pdf

last_post.content:
A Watermark for Large Language Models

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2301.10226.pdf

This is an interesting technique to watermark LLM-generated text so it’s easy to identify (even small excerpts)

Gist of it is influencing next-token prediction to prefer words from a green list, and doing this with enough frequency, that you can determine with confidence the text was machine generated.

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)
